member.remarks: In SPSS a case is analogous to a in ADO.NET.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssCase.Commit
member.summary: Writes a newly added row to the data file.
member.remarks: This method should be called after a new row has had all its values set. After calling this method, variable values may not be changed. Without calling this method, the row is never actually written to the data file.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssCase.ClearData
member.summary: Clears every variable of data for this row.
member.remarks: Remarkably, this operation is necessary for every new row, in order to prevent garbage from being placed into SPSS for the values that are never explicitly set otherwise.

member.summary: Closes an SPSS file that was opened using .

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssCloseReadDelegate
member.summary: Closes an SPSS file that was opened using .

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssCloseWriteDelegate
member.summary: Closes an SPSS file that was opened using .
member.remarks: This function closes the data file associated with handle, which must have been opened for writing using . The file handle handle becomes invalid and no further operations can be performed using it.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssCommitCaseRecordDelegate
member.summary: Writes a case to an SPSS data file after its values have been set.
member.remarks: This function writes a case to the data file specified by the handle. It must be called after setting the values of variables through and . Any variables left unset will get the system-missing value if they are numeric and all blanks if they are strings. Unless spssCommitCaseRecord is called, the case will not be written out.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssCommitHeaderDelegate
member.summary: Writes the data dictionary to the data file. To be used after dictionary defining functions are called, and before cases are written.
member.remarks: This function writes the data dictionary to the data file associated with handle. Before any case data can be written, the dictionary must be committed; once the dictionary has been committed, no further changes can be made to it.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssConvertDateDelegate
member.summary: Converts a day/month/year into SPSS format.
member.remarks: This function converts a Gregorian date expressed as day-month-year to the internal SPSS date format. The time portion of the date variable is set to 0:00. To set the time portion of the date variable to another value, use spssConvertTime and add the resulting value to *spssDate. Dates before October 15, 1582, are considered invalid.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssConvertSPSSDateDelegate
member.summary: Extracts the date from an SPSS date field.
member.remarks: This function converts the date (as distinct from time) portion of a value in internal SPSS date format to Gregorian style.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssConvertSPSSTimeDelegate
member.summary: Extracts the time of day from an SPSS date field.
member.remarks: This function breaks a value in internal SPSS date format into a day number (since October 14, 1582) plus the hour, minute, and second values. Note that the seconds value is stored in a double since it may have a fractional part.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssConvertTimeDelegate
member.summary: Converts a time of day to the SPSS time format.
member.remarks: This function converts a time given as day, hours, minutes, and seconds to the internal SPSS format. The day value is the number of days since October 14, 1582, and is typically zero, especially when this function is used in conjunction with spssConvertDate. Note that the seconds value is stored in a double since it may have a fractional part.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssCopyDocumentsDelegate
member.summary: Copies stored documents from one file to another.
member.remarks: This function copies stored documents, if any, from the file associated with fromHandle to that associated with toHandle. The latter must be open for output. If the target file already has documents, they are discarded. If the source file has no documents, the target will be set to have none, too.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetCaseSizeDelegate
member.summary: Reports the number of bytes taken up by any one case.
member.param: Pointer to size of case in bytes
member.remarks: This function reports the size of a raw case record for the file associated with handle. The case size is reported in bytes and is meant to be used in conjunction with the lowlevel case input/output procedures and .

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetCaseWeightVarDelegate
member.summary: Reports the name of the case weight variable.
member.param: Pointer to the buffer to hold name of the case weight variable
member.remarks: This function reports the name of the case weight variable. The name is copied to the buffer pointed to by varName as a null-terminated string. Since a variable name can be up to characters in length, the size of the buffer must be at least +1.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetCompressionDelegate
member.summary: Gets the compression attribute of a data file.
member.param: Pointer to compression attribute. Upon return, *compSwitch is 1 if the file is compressed; 0 otherwise.
member.remarks: This function reports the compression attribute of an SPSS data file.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetDateVariablesDelegate
member.summary: Reports TRENDS date variable information.
member.param: Number of elements in allocated array
Pointer to first element of the allocated array
member.remarks: This function reports the TRENDS date variable information, if any, in an SPSS data file. It places the information in a dynamically allocated long array, sets *numofElements to the number of elements in the array, and sets *dateInfo to point to the array. The caller is expected to free the array by calling when it is no longer needed. The variable information is copied directly from record 7, subtype 3. Its first six elements comprise the "fixed" information, followed by a sequence of one or more three-element groups.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetDEWFirstDelegate
member.summary: Retrieves the first block of SPSS Data Entry information from a data file.
member.param: Returned as data from the file
Returned as number of bytes returned
member.remarks: The client can retrieve DEW information (file information that is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) from a file in whatever increments are convenient. The first such increment is retrieved by calling spssGetDEWFirst, and subsequent segments are retrieved by calling spssGetDEWNext as many times as necessary. As with spssGetDEWInfo, spssGetDEWFirst will return SPSS_NO_DEW if the file was written with a byte order that is the reverse of that of the host.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetDEWGUIDDelegate
member.summary: Gets the Data Entry GUID from a data file.
member.param: Returned as the file's GUID in character form or a null string if the file contains no GUID
member.remarks: Data Entry for Windows maintains a GUID in character form as a uniqueness indicator. Two files have identical dictionaries and DEW information if they have the same GUID. Note that the spssOpenWriteCopy function will not copy the source files GUID. spssGetDEWGUID allows the client to read a files GUID, if any. The client supplies a 257 byte string in which the null-terminated GUID is returned.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetDEWInfoDelegate
member.summary: Gets the length and hash of the Data Entry information in a data file.
member.param: Returned as the length in bytes
member.remarks: This function can be called before actually retrieving DEW information (file information that is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) from a file, to obtain some attributes of that information--specifically its length in bytes and its hash total. The hash total is, by convention, contained in the last four bytes to be written. Because it is not cognizant of the structure of the DEW information, the I/O DLL is unable to correct the byte order of numeric information generated on a foreign host. As a result, the DEW information is discarded if the file has a byte order that is the reverse of that of the host, and calls to spssGetDEWInfo will return SPSS_NO_DEW.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetDEWNextDelegate
member.summary: Retrieves the next block of SPSS Data Entry information from a data file.
member.param: Returned as data from the file
Returned as number of bytes returned
member.remarks: The client can retrieve DEW information (file information that is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) from a file in whatever increments are convenient. The first such increment is retrieved by calling , and subsequent segments are retrieved by calling spssGetDEWNext as many times as necessary. As with , will return SPSS_NO_DEW if the file was written with a byte order that is the reverse of that of the host.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetEstimatedNofCasesDelegate
member.summary: Estimates number of cases in a data file.
member.param: Returned as estimated n of cases
member.remarks: Although not strictly required for direct access input, this function helps in reading SPSS data files from releases earlier than 6.0. Some of these data files did not contain number of cases information, and will return -1 cases. This function will return a precise number for uncompressed files and an estimate (based on overall file size) for compressed files. It cannot be used on files open for appending data.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetNumberofCasesDelegate
member.summary: Gets the number of cases in a data file.
member.remarks: This function reports the number of cases present in a data file open for reading.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetIdStringDelegate
member.summary: Gets the file label of a data file.
member.remarks: This function copies the file label of the SPSS data file associated with handle into the buffer pointed to by id. The label is at most 64 characters long and null-terminated. Thus, the size of the buffer should be at least 65. If an input data file is associated with the handle, the label will be exactly 64 characters long, padded with blanks as necessary.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetMultRespDefsDelegate
member.summary: Retrieves the definitions from a data file.
member.param: Returned as a pointer to a string
member.remarks: This function retrieves the definitions from an SPSS data file. The definitions are stored as a null-terminated ASCII string which is very similar to that containing the variable set definitions. The memory allocated by this function to contain the string must be freed by calling . If the file contains no multiple response definitions, *mrespDefs is set to NULL, and the function returns the warning code .

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetNumberofVariablesDelegate
member.summary: Gets the number of variables in a data file.
member.remarks: This function reports the number of variables present in a data file.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetReleaseInfoDelegate
member.summary: Gets information on the running version of SPSS, and the hosting computer.
member.param: Array of int in which release- and machine-specific data will be stored. This array must have at least eight elements.
member.remarks: This function reports release- and machine-specific information about the file associated with handle. The information consists of an array of eight int values copied from record type 7, subtype 3 of the file, and is useful primarily for debugging. The array elements are, in order, release number (index 0), release subnumber (1), special release identifier number (2), machine code (3), floating-point representation code (4), compression scheme code (5), big/little-endian code (6), and character representation code (7).

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetSystemStringDelegate
member.summary: Gets the name of the system that created a data file.
member.remarks: This function returns the name of the system under which the file was created. It is a 40-byte blank-padded character field corresponding to the last 40 bytes of record type 1. Thus, in order to accommodate the information, the parameter sysName must be at least 41 bytes in length plus the terminating null character.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetTextInfoDelegate
member.summary: Gets the data created by TextSmart.
member.remarks: This function places the text data created by TextSmart as a null-terminated string in the user-supplied buffer textInfo. The buffer is assumed to be at least 256 characters long; the text data may be up to 255 characters long. If text data are not present in the file, the first character in textInfo is set to NULL.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetTimeStampDelegate
member.summary: Gets the creation date of a data file, as recorded in the file itself.
member.remarks: This function returns the creation date of the file as recorded in the file itself. The creation date is a null-terminated 9-byte character field in dd mmm yy format (27 Feb 96), and the receiving field must be at least 10 bytes in length. The creation time is a nullterminated 8-byte character field in hh:mm:ss format (13:12:15), and the receiving field must be at least 9 bytes in length.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetValueCharDelegate
member.summary: Gets the string value of a variable.
member.param: Buffer for the value of the string variable
member.remarks: This function gets the value of a string variable for the current case, which is the case read by the most recent call to . The value is returned as a null-terminated string in the caller-provided buffer value; the length of the string is the length of the string variable. Argument valueSize is the allocated size of the buffer value, which must be at least the length of the variable plus 1.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetValueNumericDelegate
member.summary: Gets the numeric value of a variable.
member.param: Pointer to the value of the numeric variable
member.remarks: This function gets the value of a numeric variable for the current case, which is the case read by the most recent call to .

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarAlignmentDelegate
member.summary: Gets the alignment of a variable.
member.param: Pointer to alignment. Set to , , or
member.remarks: This function reports the value of the alignment attribute of a variable.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarCMissingValuesDelegate
member.summary: Gets the missing values of a short string variable.
member.param: Pointer to missing value format code
member.remarks: This function reports the missing values of a short string variable. The value of *missingFormat will be in the range 03, indicating the number of missing values. The appropriate number of missing values is copied to the buffers missingVal1, missingVal2, and missingVal3. The lengths of the null-terminated missing value strings will be the length of the short string variable in question. Since the latter can be at most 8 characters long, 9-character buffers are adequate for any short string variable.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarColumnWidthDelegate
member.summary: Gets the width of a variable.
member.remarks: This function reports the value of the column width attribute of a variable. A value of zero is special and means that the SPSS Data Editor, which is the primary user of this attribute, will set an appropriate width using its own algorithm.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarCValueLabelDelegate
member.summary: Gets the value label for a variable.
member.param: Short string value for which the label is wanted
member.remarks: This function gets the value label for a given value of a short string variable. The label is copied as a null-terminated string into the buffer label, whose size must be at least 61 to hold the longest possible value label (60 characters plus the null terminator). To get value labels more than 60 characters long, use the function.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarCValueLabelLongDelegate
member.summary: Gets a value label of a string variable.
member.param: Null-terminated value for which label is requested
Overall size of labelBuff in bytes
Returned as bytes stored excluding terminator
member.remarks: This function returns a null-terminated value label corresponding to one value of a specified variable whose values are short strings. The function permits the client to limit the number of bytes (including the null terminator) stored and returns the number of data bytes (excluding the null terminator) actually stored. If an error is detected, the label is returned as a null string, and the length is returned as 0.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarCValueLabelsDelegate
member.summary: Gets the list of response values and labels for a variable.
member.param: Pointer to array of pointers to values
Pointer to array of pointers to labels
Pointer to number of values or labels
member.remarks: This function gets the set of labeled values and associated labels for a short string variable. The number of values is returned as *numLabels. Values are stored into an array of *numLabels pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a null-terminated value, and *values is set to point to the first element of the array. Each value string is as long as the variable. The corresponding labels are structured as an array of *numLabels pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a null-terminated label, and *labels is set to point to the first element of the array. The two arrays and the value and label strings are allocated on the heap. When they are no longer needed, should be called to free the memory.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarHandleDelegate
member.summary: Gets the handle for a named variable.
member.param: Pointer to handle for the variable. Note that the variable handle is a double, and not int or long.
member.remarks: This function returns a handle for a variable, which can then be used to read or write (depending on how the file was opened) values of the variable. If handle is associated with an output file, the dictionary must be written with before variable handles can be obtained via spssGetVarHandle.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVariableSetsDelegate
member.summary: Gets variable sets information in a data file.
member.param: Pointer to pointer to variable sets string
member.remarks: This function reports the variable sets information in the data file. Variable sets information is stored in a null-terminated string and a pointer to the string is returned in *varSets. Since the variable sets string is allocated on the heap, the caller should free it by calling when it is no longer needed.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarInfoDelegate
member.summary: Gets the name and type of a variable.
member.remarks: This function gets the name and type of one of the variables present in a data file. It serves the same purpose as but returns the information one variable at a time and, therefore, can be passed to a Visual Basic program. The storage to receive the variable name must be at least 9 bytes in length because the name is returned as a null-terminated string. The type code is an integer in the range 0255, 0 indicating a numeric variable and a positive value indicating a string variable of that size.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarLabelDelegate
member.summary: Gets the variable label for some named variable.
member.remarks: This function copies the label of variable varName into the buffer pointed to by varLabel. Since the variable label is at most 120 characters long and null terminated, the size of the buffer should be at least 121. To get labels more than 120 characters long, use the spssGetVarLabelLong function.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarLabelLongDelegate
member.summary: Gets the variable label for some named variable.
member.param: Buffer to receive the null-terminated label
Overall size of labelBuff in bytes
Returned as bytes stored excluding terminator
member.remarks: This function returns the null-terminated label associated with the specified variable but restricts the number of bytes (including the null terminator) returned to lenBuff bytes. This length can be conveniently specified as sizeof(labelBuff). The function also returns the number of data bytes (this time excluding the null terminator) stored. If an error is detected, the label is returned as a null string, and the length is returned as 0.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarMeasureLevelDelegate
member.summary: Gets the measurement level of a variable.
member.param: Pointer to measurement level. Set to , , or , for nominal, ordinal, and scale (ratio), respectively
member.remarks: This function reports the value of the measurement level attribute of a variable.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarNMissingValuesDelegate
member.summary: Gets the missing values of a numeric variable.
member.param: Pointer to missing value format code
member.remarks: This function reports the missing values of a numeric variable. The value of *missingFormat determines the interpretation of *missingVal1, *missingVal2, and *missingVal3. If *missingFormat is SPSS_MISS_RANGE, *missingVal1 and *missingVal2 represent the upper and lower limits, respectively, of the range, and *missingVal3 is not used. If *missingFormat is SPSS_MISS_RANGEANDVAL, *missingVal1 and *missingVal2 represent the range and *missingVal3 is the discrete missing value. If *missingFormat is neither of the above, it will be in the range 03, indicating the number of discrete missing values present. (The macros SPSS_NO_MISSVAL, SPSS_ONE_MISSVAL, SPSS_TWO_MISSVAL, and SPSS_THREE_MISSVAL may be used as synonyms for 03.)

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarNValueLabelDelegate
member.summary: Gets the value label for a given value of a numeric variable.
member.param: Numeric value for which the label is wanted
member.remarks: This function gets the value label for a given value of a numeric variable. The label is copied as a null-terminated string into the buffer label, whose size must be at least 61 to hold the longest possible value label (60 characters) plus the terminator. To get value labels more than 60 characters long, use the function.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarNValueLabelLongDelegate
member.summary: Gets the value label for a given value of a numeric variable.
member.param: Value for which label is requested
Overall size of labelBuff in bytes
Returned as bytes stored excluding terminator
member.remarks: This function returns a null-terminated value label corresponding to one value of a specified numeric variable. It permits the client to limit the number of bytes (including the null terminator) stored and returns the number of data bytes (excluding the null terminator) actually stored. If an error is detected, the label is returned as a null string, and the length is returned as 0.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarNValueLabelsDelegate
member.summary: Gets a list of all response values and labels for a numeric variable.
member.param: Pointer to array of double values
Pointer to array of pointers to labels
Pointer to number of values or labels
member.remarks: This function gets the set of labeled values and associated labels for a numeric variable. The number of values is returned as *numLabels. Values are stored into an array of *numLabels double elements, and *values is set to point to the first element of the array. The corresponding labels are structured as an array of *numLabels pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a null-terminated label, and *labels is set to point to the first element of the array. The two arrays and the label strings are allocated on the heap. When they are no longer needed, should be called to free the memory.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarPrintFormatDelegate
member.summary: Gets print formatting information for a variable.
member.param: Pointer to print format type code (file spssdio.h defines macros of the form SPSS_FMT_... for all valid format type codes)
Pointer to number of digits after the decimal
member.remarks: This function reports the print format of a variable. Format type, number of decimal places, and field width are returned as *printType, *printDec, and *printWid, respectively.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarNamesDelegate
member.summary: Gets the names and types of all variables in a data file.
member.param: Pointer to array of pointers to variable names
Pointer to array of variable types
member.remarks: This function gets the names and types of all the variables present in a data file. The number of variables is returned as *numVars. Variable names are structured as an array of *numVars pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a variable name, and *varNames is set to point to the first element of the array. Variable types are stored into a corresponding array of *numVars in elements, and *varTypes is set to point to the first element of the array. The type code is an integer in the range 0255, 0 indicating a numeric variable and a positive value indicating a string variable of that size. The two arrays and the variable name strings are allocated on the heap. When they are no longer needed, should be called to free the memory.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssGetVarWriteFormatDelegate

Pointer to number of digits after the decimal
member.remarks: This function reports the write format of a variable. Format type, number of decimal places, and field width are returned as *writeType, *writeDec, and *writeWid, respectively.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssHostSysmisValDelegate
member.summary: Gets the missing value for the system.
member.param: Returned as the system missing value
member.remarks: This function accesses the same information as but returns the information via a parameter rather than on the stack as the function result. The problem being addressed is that not all languages return doubles from functions in the same fashion.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssLowHighValDelegate
member.summary: Gets the lowest and highest values used for numeric missing values on the system.
member.remarks: This function returns the "lowest" and "highest" values used for numeric missing value ranges on the host system. It may be called at any time.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssOpenAppendDelegate
member.summary: Opens an SPSS file for appending cases.
member.param: Pointer to handle to be returned
member.remarks: This function opens an SPSS data file for appending cases and returns a handle that should be used for subsequent operations on the file.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssOpenReadDelegate
member.summary: Opens an SPSS file for reading.
member.param: Pointer to handle to be returned
member.remarks: This function opens an SPSS data file for reading and returns a handle that should be used for subsequent operations on the file.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssOpenWriteDelegate
member.summary: Creates an SPSS file, and prepares for writing.
member.param: Pointer to handle to be returned
member.remarks: This function opens a file in preparation for creating a new SPSS data file and returns a handle that should be used for subsequent operations on the file.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssOpenWriteCopyDelegate
member.summary: Creates a new SPSS data file, with a dictionary copied from an existing file.
member.param: Pointer to handle to be returned
member.remarks: This function opens a file in preparation for creating a new SPSS data file and initializes its dictionary from that of an existing SPSS data file. It is useful when you want to modify the dictionary or data of an existing file or replace all of its data. The typical sequence of operations is to call (newFileName, oldFileName, ...) to open a new file initialized with a copy of the old files dictionary, then (oldFile- Name, ...) to open the old file to access its data.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssQueryType7Delegate
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a data file contains a specific "type 7" record.
member.param: Returned set if the specified subtype was encountered
member.remarks:
This function can be used to determine whether a file opened for reading or append contains a specific "type 7" record. The following type 7 subtypes might be of interest:
Subtype 3. Release information
Subtype 4. Floating point constants including the system missing value
Subtype 5. Variable set definitions
Subtype 6. Date variable information
Subtype 7. Multiple response set definitions
Subtype 8. Data Entry for Windows (DEW) information
Subtype 10. TextSmart information
Subtype 11. Measurement level, column width, and alignment for each variable

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssReadCaseRecordDelegate
member.summary: Reads the next case from a data file in preparation for reading its values.
member.remarks: This function reads the next case from a data file into internal buffers. Values of individual variables for the case may then be obtained by calling the and procedures.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSeekNextCaseDelegate
member.summary: Prepares SPSS to read data values from a specific case.
member.remarks: This function sets the file pointer of an input file so that the next data case read will be the one specified via the caseNumber parameter. A zero origin scheme is used. That is, the first case is number 0. The next case can be read by calling either or . If the specified case is greater than or equal to the number of cases in the file, the call to the input function will return .

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetCaseWeightVarDelegate
member.summary: Sets the case weight variable in a data file.
member.param: The name of the case weight variable
member.remarks: This function defines variable varName as the case weight variable for the data file specified by the handle.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetCompressionDelegate
member.summary: Sets the compression attribute of a data file.
member.remarks: This function sets the compression attribute of an SPSS data file. Compression is set on if compSwitch is one and off if it is zero. If this function is not called, the output file will be uncompressed by default.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetDateVariablesDelegate
member.summary: Sets the Trends date variable information.
member.remarks: This function sets the Trends date variable information. The array at dateInfo is assumed to have numofElements elements that correspond to the data array portion of record 7, subtype 3. Its first six elements comprise the fixed information, followed by a sequence of one or more three-element groups. Since very little validity checking is done on the input array, this function should be used with caution and is recommended only for copying Trends information from one file to another.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetDEWFirstDelegate
member.summary: Sets the first block of Data Entry information.
member.param: Pointer to the data to be written
member.remarks: DEW information (file information which is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) can be delivered to the I/O DLL in whatever segments are convenient for the client. The spssSetDEWFirst function is called to deliver the first such segment, and subsequent segments are delivered by calling spssSetDEWNext as many times as necessary.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetDEWGUIDDelegate
member.summary: Sets the unique Data Entry uniqueness GUID.
member.param: The GUID (as a null-terminated string) to be stored on the file
member.remarks: This function stores the Data Entry for Windows uniqueness indicator on the data file. It should only be used by the DEW product.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetDEWNextDelegate
member.summary: Sets the next block of information for Data Entry.
member.param: Pointer to the data to be written
member.remarks: The DEW information (file information that is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) can be delivered to the I/O DLL in whatever segments are convenient for the client. The spssSetDEWFirst function is called to deliver the first such segment, and subsequent segments are delivered by calling spssSetDEWNext as many times as necessary.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetIdStringDelegate
member.summary: Sets the file label of a data file.
member.param: File label. The length of the string should not exceed 64 characters
member.remarks: This function sets the file label of the output SPSS data file associated with handle to the given string id.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetMultRespDefsDelegate
member.summary: Sets multiple response definitions to a data file.
member.remarks: this function is used to write multiple response definitions to the file. the definitions consist of a single null-terminated ascii string which is similar to that containing the variable set definitions.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetTextInfoDelegate
member.summary: Sets the text data from the null-terminated string in textInfo.
member.remarks: This function sets the text data from the null-terminated string in textInfo. If the string is longer than 255 characters, only the first 255 are (quietly) used. If textInfo contains the empty string, existing text data, if any, is deleted.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetValueCharDelegate
member.summary: Sets the value of a string variable.
member.param: Value of the variable as a null-terminated string. The length of the string (ignoring trailing blanks, if any) should be less than or equal to the length of the variable.
member.remarks: This function sets the value of a string variable for the current case. The current case is not written out to the data file until is called.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetValueNumericDelegate
member.summary: Sets the value of a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function sets the value of a numeric variable for the current case. The current case is not written out to the data file until is called.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarAlignmentDelegate
member.summary: Sets the alignment of a variable.
member.param: Alignment. Must be one of , , or . If not a legal value, alignment is set to a type-appropriate default
member.remarks: This function sets the value of the alignment attribute of a variable.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarCMissingValuesDelegate
member.summary: Sets missing values for a short string variable.
member.param: The number of missing values (0-3) actually supplied.
member.remarks: This function sets missing values for a short string variable. The argument missingFormat must be set to a value in the range 03 to indicate the number of missing values supplied. When fewer than three missing values are to be defined, the redundant arguments must still be present, although their values are not inspected. For example, if missingFormat is 2, missingVal3 is unused. The supplied missing values must be nullterminated and not longer than the length of the variable unless the excess length is made up of blanks, which are ignored. If the missing value is shorter than the length of the variable, trailing blanks are assumed.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarColumnWidthDelegate
member.summary: Sets the column width of a variable.
member.param: Column width. If negative, a value of zero is (quietly) used instead
member.remarks: This function sets the value of the column width attribute of a variable. A value of zero is special and means that the SPSS Data Editor, which is the primary user of this attribute, is to set an appropriate width using its own algorithm.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarCValueLabelDelegate
member.summary: Changes or adds a value label for a short string variable.
member.remarks: This function changes or adds a value label for the specified value of a short string variable. The label should be a null-terminated string not exceeding 60 characters in length.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVariableSetsDelegate
member.summary: Sets the variable sets information in a data file.
member.remarks: This function sets the variable sets information in the data file. The information must be provided in the form of a null-terminated string. No validity checks are performed on the supplied string beyond ensuring that its length is not 0. Any existing variable sets information is discarded.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarLabelDelegate
member.summary: Sets the label of a variable.
member.param: Variable label. The length of the string should not exceed 120 characters. If varLabel is the empty string, the existing label, if any, is deleted.
member.remarks: This function sets the label of a variable.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarMeasureLevelDelegate
member.summary: Sets the measurement level of a variable.
member.param: Measurement level. Must be one of , , , or for nominal, ordinal, scale (ratio), and unknown, respectively. If , measurement level is set to a type-appropriate default.
member.remarks: This function sets the value of the measurement level attribute of a variable.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarNameDelegate
member.summary: Creates a new variable with a given name.
member.param: Type and size of the variable

item.description: The file handle is not valid
File is open for reading, not writing
Dictionary has already been written with
Invalid length code ( varLength is negative or exceeds 255)
There is already a variable with the same name

member.remarks: This function creates a new variable named varName, which will be either numeric or string based on varLength. If the latter is zero, a numeric variable with a default format of F8.2 will be created; if it is greater than 0 and less than or equal to 255, a string variable with length varLength will be created; any other value will be rejected as invalid. For better readability, macros SPSS_NUMERIC and SPSS_STRING( length) may be used as values for varLength.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarNMissingValuesDelegate
member.summary: Sets the missing values for a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function sets missing values for a numeric variable. The interpretation of the arguments missingVal1, missingVal2, and missingVal3 depends on the value of missingFormat. If missingFormat is set to SPSS_MISS_RANGE, missingVal1 and missingVal2 are taken as the upper and lower limits, respectively, of the range, and missingVal3 is ignored. If missingFormat is SPSS_MISS_RANGEANDVAL, missingval1 and missingVal2 are taken as limits of the range and missingVal3 is taken as the discrete missing value. If missingFormat is neither of the above, it must be in the range 03, indicating the number of discrete missing values present. For example, if missingFormat is 2, missingVal1 and missingVal2 are taken as two discrete missing values and missingVal3 is ignored. (The macros SPSS_NO_MISSVAL, SPSS_ONE_MISSVAL, SPSS_TWO_MISSVAL, and SPSS_THREE_MISSVAL may be used as synonyms for 03.)

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssSetVarNValueLabelDelegate
member.summary: Changes or adds a value label to a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function changes or adds a value label for the specified value of a numeric variable. The label should be a null-terminated string not exceeding 60 characters in length.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssWholeCaseInDelegate
member.summary: Reads in the raw data for an entire case.
member.remarks: This function reads a case from a data file into a case buffer provided by the user. The required size of the buffer may be obtained by calling . This is a fairly low-level function whose use should not be mixed with calls to using the same file handle because both procedures read a new case from the data file.

member.name: T:Spss.SpssThinWrapper.spssWholeCaseOutDelegate
member.summary: Writes out raw data as a case.
member.param: Case record to be written to the data file
member.remarks: This function writes a case assembled by the caller to a data file. The case is assumed to have been constructed correctly in the buffer caseRec, and its validity is not checked. This is a fairly low-level function whose use should not be mixed with calls to using the same file handle because both procedures write a new case to the data file.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetDEWFirst(System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the first block of SPSS Data Entry information from a data file.
member.remarks: The client can retrieve DEW information (file information that is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) from a file in whatever increments are convenient. The first such increment is retrieved by calling spssGetDEWFirst, and subsequent segments are retrieved by calling spssGetDEWNext as many times as necessary. As with spssGetDEWInfo, spssGetDEWFirst will return SPSS_NO_DEW if the file was written with a byte order that is the reverse of that of the host.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetDEWGUID(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets the Data Entry GUID from a data file.
member.param: The file's GUID in character form or a null string if the file contains no GUID.
member.remarks: Data Entry for Windows maintains a GUID in character form as a uniqueness indicator. Two files have identical dictionaries and DEW information if they have the same GUID. Note that the spssOpenWriteCopy function will not copy the source files GUID. spssGetDEWGUID allows the client to read a files GUID, if any.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetDEWNext(System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the next block of SPSS Data Entry information from a data file.
member.remarks: The client can retrieve DEW information (file information that is private to the SPSS Data Entry product) from a file in whatever increments are convenient. The first such increment is retrieved by calling , and subsequent segments are retrieved by calling spssGetDEWNext as many times as necessary. As with , will return SPSS_NO_DEW if the file was written with a byte order that is the reverse of that of the host.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetIdString(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets the file label of a data file.
member.remarks: This function retrieves the file label of the SPSS data file associated with handle into the id parameter.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetReleaseInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32[]@)
member.summary: Gets information on the running version of SPSS, and the hosting computer.
member.param: Array of in which release- and machine-specific data will be stored.
member.remarks: This function reports release- and machine-specific information about the file associated with handle. The information consists of an array of eight int values copied from record type 7, subtype 3 of the file, and is useful primarily for debugging. The array elements are, in order, release number (index 0), release subnumber (1), special release identifier number (2), machine code (3), floating-point representation code (4), compression scheme code (5), big/little-endian code (6), and character representation code (7).

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetSystemString(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets the name of the system that created a data file.
member.remarks: This function returns the name of the system under which the file was created.

member.summary: Gets the data created by TextSmart.
member.remarks: This function retrieves the text data created by TextSmart.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetTimeStamp(System.Int32,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets the creation date of a data file, as recorded in the file itself.
member.remarks: This function returns the creation date of the file as recorded in the file itself. The creation date is a 9-byte string in dd mmm yy format (27 Feb 96). The creation time is a 8-byte oypcbi in hh:mm:ss format (13:12:15).

member.remarks: This function reports the missing values of a short string variable. The value of missingFormat will indicate the number of missing values. The appropriate number of missing values is copied to the missingVal1, missingVal2, and missingVal3 parameters.

member.remarks: This function reports the value of the column width attribute of a variable. A value of zero is special and means that the SPSS Data Editor, which is the primary user of this attribute, will set an appropriate width using its own algorithm.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetVarInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Gets the name and type of a variable.
member.remarks: This function gets the name and type of one of the variables present in a data file. It serves the same purpose as but returns the information one variable at a time and, therefore, can be passed to a Visual Basic program. The type code is an integer in the range 0255, 0 indicating a numeric variable and a positive value indicating a string variable of that size.

member.summary: Gets the handle for a named variable.
member.remarks: This function returns a handle for a variable, which can then be used to read or write (depending on how the file was opened) values of the variable. If handle is associated with an output file, the dictionary must be written with before variable handles can be obtained via spssGetVarHandle.

member.summary: Gets the missing values of a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function reports the missing values of a numeric variable. The value of missingFormat determines the interpretation of missingVal1, missingVal2, and missingVal3. If missingFormat is SPSS_MISS_RANGE, missingVal1 and missingVal2 represent the upper and lower limits, respectively, of the range, and missingVal3 is not used. member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssOpenWriteCopy(System.String,System.String,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Creates a new SPSS data file, with a dictionary copied from an existing file.
member.remarks: This function opens a file in preparation for creating a new SPSS data file and initializes its dictionary from that of an existing SPSS data file. It is useful when you want to modify the dictionary or data of an existing file or replace all of its data. The typical sequence of operations is to call (newFileName, oldFileName, ...) to open a new file initialized with a copy of the old files dictionary, then (oldFile- Name, ...) to open the old file to access its data.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssSetDateVariables(System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Sets the Trends date variable information.
member.remarks: This function sets the Trends date variable information. The array at dateInfo is assumed to have numofElements elements that correspond to the data array portion of record 7, subtype 3. Its first six elements comprise the fixed information, followed by a sequence of one or more three-element groups. Since very little validity checking is done on the input array, this function should be used with caution and is recommended only for copying Trends information from one file to another.

member.summary: Sets the missing values for a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function sets missing values for a numeric variable. The interpretation of the arguments missingVal1, missingVal2, and missingVal3 depends on the value of missingFormat. If missingFormat is set to SPSS_MISS_RANGE, missingVal1 and missingVal2 are taken as the upper and lower limits, respectively, of the range, and missingVal3 is ignored. If missingFormat is SPSS_MISS_RANGEANDVAL, missingval1 and missingVal2 are taken as limits of the range and missingVal3 is taken as the discrete missing value. If missingFormat is neither of the above, it must be in the range 03, indicating the number of discrete missing values present. For example, if missingFormat is 2, missingVal1 and missingVal2 are taken as two discrete missing values and missingVal3 is ignored. (The macros SPSS_NO_MISSVAL, SPSS_ONE_MISSVAL, SPSS_TWO_MISSVAL, and SPSS_THREE_MISSVAL may be used as synonyms for 03.)

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssSetVarNValueLabel(System.Int32,System.String,System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Changes or adds a value label to a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function changes or adds a value label for the specified value of a numeric variable. The label should not exceed 60 characters in length.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssWholeCaseIn(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Reads in the raw data for an entire case.
member.remarks: This function reads a case from a data file into a case buffer provided by the user. The required size of the buffer may be obtained by calling . This is a fairly low-level function whose use should not be mixed with calls to using the same file handle because both procedures read a new case from the data file.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssWholeCaseOut(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Writes out raw data as a case.
member.param: Case record to be written to the data file.
member.remarks: This function writes a case assembled by the caller to a data file. The case is assumed to have been constructed correctly in the buffer caseRec, and its validity is not checked. This is a fairly low-level function whose use should not be mixed with calls to using the same file handle because both procedures write a new case to the data file.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetVariableSets(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets variable sets information in a data file.
member.remarks: This function reports the variable sets information in the data file.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetDateVariables(System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Reports TRENDS date variable information.
member.param: Pointer to first element of the allocated array.
member.remarks: This function reports the TRENDS date variable information, if any, in an SPSS data file. It places the information in a dynamically allocated long array, sets *numofElements to the number of elements in the array, and sets *dateInfo to point to the array. The caller is expected to free the array by calling when it is no longer needed. The variable information is copied directly from record 7, subtype 3. Its first six elements comprise the "fixed" information, followed by a sequence of one or more three-element groups.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetMultRespDefs(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Retrieves the definitions from a data file.
member.remarks: This function retrieves the definitions from an SPSS data file. The definitions are stored as a null-terminated ASCII string which is very similar to that containing the variable set definitions. The memory allocated by this function to contain the string must be freed by calling . If the file contains no multiple response definitions, *mrespDefs is set to NULL, and the function returns the warning code .

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetVarNValueLabels(System.Int32,System.String,System.Double[]@,System.String[]@)
member.summary: Gets a list of all response values and labels for a numeric variable.
member.remarks: This function gets the set of labeled values and associated labels for a numeric variable. The number of values is returned as *numLabels. Values are stored into an array of *numLabels double elements, and *values is set to point to the first element of the array. The corresponding labels are structured as an array of *numLabels pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a null-terminated label, and *labels is set to point to the first element of the array. The two arrays and the label strings are allocated on the heap. When they are no longer needed, should be called to free the memory.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetVarCValueLabels(System.Int32,System.String,System.String[]@,System.String[]@)
member.summary: Gets the list of response values and labels for a variable.
member.remarks: This function gets the set of labeled values and associated labels for a short string variable. The number of values is returned as *numLabels. Values are stored into an array of *numLabels pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a null-terminated value, and *values is set to point to the first element of the array. Each value string is as long as the variable. The corresponding labels are structured as an array of *numLabels pointers, each pointing to a char string containing a null-terminated label, and *labels is set to point to the first element of the array. The two arrays and the value and label strings are allocated on the heap. When they are no longer needed, should be called to free the memory.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssSafeWrapper.spssGetVarNames(System.Int32,System.String[]@,System.Int32[]@)
member.summary: Reports on all the variables in a data file, including names and types.
member.param: The array to fill with variable names
The array to fill with variable types
member.remarks: This function gets the names and types of all the variables present in a data file. The type code is an integer in the range 0-255, 0 indicating a numeric variable and a positive value indicating a string variable of that size.

member.name: M:Spss.SpssVariablesCollection.GenerateColumnName(System.String)
member.summary: Comes up with a variable name guaranteed to be short enough to fit within the limits of SPSS.
member.param: The initially suggested name for a variable.
member.returns: The original variable name, if it was within SPSS limits. Otherwise, it applies a string shortening algorithm and returns the shorter variable name.
member.remarks: The shortening algorithm takes the first and last several characters of the variable name and concatenates them together such that the resulting string is exactly the allowed length for a variable name. The process is not guaranteed to produce a unique variable name.
